title-group.article-title: Endoscopic Endonasal Resection of Extensive Anterior Skull Base Sinonasal Osteoblastoma

body.p: Osteoblastomas are uncommon neoplasms that account for approximately 1% to 4% of primary bone neoplasms.1 They are characterized as slow-growing, expansile lesions and usually occur in younger males, commonly affecting the vertebral column or long bones of the skeleton. However, osteoblastomas can occur in any bony structure, including the craniofacial skeleton. Sinonasal osteoblastomas are particularly rare, with only a few cases previously reported.2-4 We report a rare case of extensive sinonasal skull base osteoblastoma in an adolescent girl. Institutional review board approval was obtained at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey–New Jersey Medical School.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 15-year-old girl presented with progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent sinusitis, anosmia, right eye proptosis, and diplopia. Nasal endoscopy revealed a deviated nasal septum to the left with a large right nasal mass. Computed tomography (CT) scan and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a heterogeneous mass measuring 6.5 × 4.5 × 7.3 cm within the right sinonasal cavity with erosion of the anterior skull base and the right lamina papyracea (Figure 1A-D). Endoscopic biopsy was suspicious for an ossifying fibroma. The patient underwent a purely endoscopic endonasal resection of the lesion (Figure 1E). Intraoperatively, the frontal lobe dura adjacent to the posterior frontal sinus table was exposed but not violated. Final pathologic analysis was consistent with osteoblastoma (Figure 1F). Postoperative CT scan confirmed gross total resection (Figure 2A, B). The patient’s postoperative course was unremarkable, and her orbital proptosis resolved.

caption.p: Coronal (A), axial (B), and sagittal (C) computed tomography (CT) scans show an extensive right sinonasal mass with orbital and intracranial extension. Axial (D) magnetic resonance imaging confirms the CT findings. (E) Intraoperative sinonasal cavity after resection. (F) Hematoxylin and eosin 400×, connective tissue stroma with osteoclast-type giant cells and osteoid consistent with osteoblastoma.

Coronal (A) and axial (B) immediate postoperative computed tomography (CT). (C) Eight-month postoperative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). (D) Intraoperative tumor and anterior skull base resection. (E) Immediate postoperative CT. (F) Four-month postoperative MRI.

sec.p: At 8-month follow-up, MRI revealed small recurrences at the anterior skull base and right lamina papyracea (Figure 2C). The patient underwent endoscopic resection of the lamina papyracea recurrence and endoscopic skull base resection of the recurrent tumors at the cranial base with skull base reconstruction using a nasoseptal flap (Figure 2D). Immediate postoperative CT revealed adequate resection (Figure 2E). Her postoperative care was uneventful without cerebrospinal fluid leakage. Her 4-month postoperative MRI showed no recurrence (Figure 2F).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Osteoblastomas are rare benign bone tumors, typically affecting the lower extremity long bones and vertebral column. Progressive pain is the most common presenting symptom.1 Sinonasal osteoblastomas are exceedingly rare and present with progressive nasal obstruction, headache, proptosis, and visual distortion.

Radiographically, osteoblastomas have a variable appearance. Most appear as expansile lesions with an area of central lucency surrounded by a sclerotic rim of bony tissues with adjacent bone remodeling.3 These tumors tend to remain well circumscribed without bony destruction. Some lesions have discrete areas of organized bone density, while others have a mixed osseous and fibrous appearance.3 The latter tend to be more nodular and more coarsely organized than most ossifying fibromas and some fibrous dysplasias.2

Histologically, osteoblastomas are composed of anastamosing trabeculae of woven bone set within loose fibrovascular stroma, with or without a central sclerotic nidus.1,5 However, as with the radiological appearance, their microscopic appearance can also vary. There is a wide range of bony maturational changes that can appear, ranging from cords and clusters of activated osteoblasts with minimal osteoid, to wispy osteoid, to broad anastomosing trabeculae of woven bone, to sclerotic sheets of woven bone.1 Importantly, the cortex of the surrounding bone should remain intact, and there should be no invasion of the surrounding soft tissue.1

Differential diagnoses for an expansile bony lesion of the paranasal sinuses include osteoid osteoma, aneurysmal bone cyst, giant cell tumor of bone, osteosarcoma, and osteoma with osteoblastoma-like features. Of these, it is most important to distinguish between osteoblastomas and osteomas with osteoblastoma-like features. Unlike oteoblastomas that are rare, osteomas are the most frequently encountered bony tumor of the paranasal sinuses.5 They consist of mature compact or trabecular bone, usually causing a polypoid growth in the paranasal sinuses or orbits.5 However, histologically, up to 40% of osteomas have areas of immature woven bone in an edematous loose fibrovascular stroma, similar to the histologic appearance of osteoblastomas.1,5 Therefore, careful histologic examination is needed to fully distinguish between these 2 entities.1,5

Our patient presented with an extensive osteoblastoma that was resected purely endoscopically. Traditionally, this type of lesion would have required an external or combined cranionasal approach, which might not be cosmetically desirable in this young female patient. These tumors, despite their histopathologic features and size, can be successfully removed using endoscopic endonasal skull base techniques without the morbidity of an open approach.
